**Gilbert Gottfried**[1] (born February 28, 1955) is an American stand-up
comedian, actor and voice actor. His numerous roles in film and television
include voicing the parrot [Iago](/wiki/Iago_\(Disney_character\) "Iago
\(Disney character\)") in Disney's
_[Aladdin](/wiki/Aladdin_\(1992_Disney_film\) "Aladdin \(1992 Disney film\)")_
, Digit in the children's cartoon/educational math-based show
_[Cyberchase](/wiki/Cyberchase "Cyberchase")_ and Kraang Subprime in _[Teenage
Mutant Ninja Turtles](/wiki/Teenage_Mutant_Ninja_Turtles_\(2012_TV_series\)
"Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles \(2012 TV series\)")_. Gottfried was also the
voice of the [Aflac Duck](/wiki/Aflac_Duck "Aflac Duck") until 2011.

Since 2014, Gottfried has hosted a [podcast](/wiki/Podcast "Podcast") titled
_Gilbert Gottfried 's Amazing Colossal Podcast_, which airs new episodes each
week featuring discussions of classic movies and celebrity interviews, most
often with veteran actors, comedians and comedy writers.[2]

##
Career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gilbert_Gottfried&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Career")]

### Early career
(1970–1998)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gilbert_Gottfried&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Early career \(1970–1998\)")]

At age 15, Gottfried began doing amateur stand-up in [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") and, after a few years, became
known around New York as "the comedian's comedian."[3] In 1980, _[Saturday
Night Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live "Saturday Night Live")_ was being
retooled with a new staff and new comedians; the producers noticed Gottfried
and hired him as a cast member for [season
6](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live_\(season_6\) "Saturday Night Live \(season
6\)").[4] Gottfried's [persona](/wiki/Persona "Persona") in _SNL_ sketches was
very different from his later characterization: he rarely (if ever) spoke in
his trademark screeching, obnoxious voice and never squinted. During his
12-episode stint, he was given very little airtime and seldom used in
sketches. Gottfried recalls a low point was having to play a corpse in a
sketch about a sports organist hired to play inappropriate music at a funeral.
Despite this, he had one recurring character (Leo Waxman, husband to [Denny
Dillon](/wiki/Denny_Dillon "Denny Dillon")'s Pinky Waxman on the recurring
talk show sketch, "What's It All About?") and two celebrity impersonations:
[David A. Stockman](/wiki/David_A._Stockman "David A. Stockman") and
controversial film director [Roman Polanski](/wiki/Roman_Polanski "Roman
Polanski").[5]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/15/GilbertGottfried.jpg)](/wiki/File:GilbertGottfried.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:GilbertGottfried.jpg "Enlarge")

Gottfried at the 1991 Emmy Awards

Gottfried also played accountant Sidney Bernstein in the 1987 film _[Beverly
Hills Cop II](/wiki/Beverly_Hills_Cop_II "Beverly Hills Cop II")_.

Although not a regular, he also appeared in _[The Amazing Live Sea
Monkeys](/wiki/The_Amazing_Live_Sea_Monkeys "The Amazing Live Sea Monkeys")_ ,
as well as voicing the crazed dentist Dr. Bender and his son Wendell in _[The
Fairly OddParents](/wiki/The_Fairly_OddParents "The Fairly OddParents")_ and
the voice of Jerry the Belly Button Elf on _[Ren and
Stimpy](/wiki/Ren_and_Stimpy "Ren and Stimpy")_. Three of his most prominent
roles came in 1990, 1991, and 1992, when he was cast as the adoption agent
[Igor Peabody](/wiki/Problem_Child_\(film\)#Cast "Problem Child \(film\)") in
_[Problem Child](/wiki/Problem_Child_\(film\) "Problem Child \(film\)")_ and
_[Problem Child 2](/wiki/Problem_Child_2 "Problem Child 2")_ and the parrot
[Iago](/wiki/Iago_\(Aladdin\)#Iago "Iago \(Aladdin\)") in
_[Aladdin](/wiki/Aladdin_\(1992_Disney_film\) "Aladdin \(1992 Disney
film\)")_. When asked how he prepared for the role, Gottfried said, "I did the
whole [DeNiro](/wiki/Robert_De_Niro "Robert De Niro") thing. I moved to [South
America](/wiki/South_America "South America")! I lived in the trees!"
Gottfried reprised the role in _[Aladdin: The Return of
Jafar](/wiki/Aladdin:_The_Return_of_Jafar "Aladdin: The Return of Jafar")_ ,
_[Aladdin and the King of Thieves](/wiki/Aladdin_and_the_King_of_Thieves
"Aladdin and the King of Thieves")_ , the [television
series](/wiki/Aladdin_\(TV_series\) "Aladdin \(TV series\)") and various
related media, such as _[Kingdom Hearts](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts "Kingdom
Hearts")_ and _[House of Mouse](/wiki/Disney%27s_House_of_Mouse "Disney's
House of Mouse")_. Gottfried also voiced Berkely Beetle in 1994's Thumbelina.

In 1996, he starred as a talking smoke detector, in "Be Cool about Fire
Safety," a short fire safety video for younger audiences.

Gottfried was the host of the Saturday edition of _[USA Up All
Night](/wiki/USA_Up_All_Night "USA Up All Night")_ for its entire run from
1989 to 1998.

### Voice acting, television and films
(1999–present)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gilbert_Gottfried&action=edit&section=3&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Voice acting, television and films \(1999–present\)")]

On the most recent version of _[Hollywood Squares](/wiki/Hollywood_Squares
"Hollywood Squares")_ , Gottfried was a regular guest. On one particular
episode, he was the last square on the board for a five-square win, but both
contestants repeatedly got his answers wrong, prompting Gottfried to yell "YOU
FOOL!" with every incorrect response. It took seven tries before a contestant
finally correctly agreed with him, specifically on a question of "smog" being
a combination of smoke and fog.

Gottfried has provided the voice of the duck in the [Aflac](/wiki/Aflac
"Aflac") commercials and [Digit](/wiki/Digit_\(Cyberchase\) "Digit
\(Cyberchase\)") in _[Cyberchase](/wiki/Cyberchase "Cyberchase")_ , as well as
[Mr. Mxyzptlk](/wiki/Mr._Mxyzptlk "Mr. Mxyzptlk") in _[Superman: The Animated
Series](/wiki/Superman:_The_Animated_Series "Superman: The Animated Series")_.
He also voiced a nasty wisecracking criminal genius named Nick-Nack in two
episodes of _[Superboy](/wiki/Superboy_\(TV_series\) "Superboy \(TV
series\)")_ (he also co-wrote an issue of _[Superboy: The Comic
Book](/wiki/Superboy:_The_Comic_Book "Superboy: The Comic Book")_ , which
featured Nick-Nack's origin). On _[The Tonight Show with Jay
Leno](/wiki/The_Tonight_Show_with_Jay_Leno "The Tonight Show with Jay Leno")_
, Gottfried has made regular appearances.

In 2004, [Comedy Central](/wiki/Comedy_Central "Comedy Central") featured
Gottfried's stand-up material for _[Shorties Watchin'
Shorties](/wiki/Shorties_Watchin%27_Shorties "Shorties Watchin'
Shorties")_.[6] Gottfried was part of an online advertising campaign for
[Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft")'s [Office XP](/wiki/Office_XP "Office
XP") [software](/wiki/Software "Software"), showing, in a series of [Flash-
animated](/wiki/Flash-animated "Flash-animated") [cartoons](/wiki/Cartoon
"Cartoon"), that the [Clippy](/wiki/Clippy "Clippy") office assistant would be
removed. In 2006, Gottfried topped the _[Boston Phoenix](/wiki/Boston_Phoenix
"Boston Phoenix")_ 's tongue-in-cheek list of the world's 100 Unsexiest Men.
In April 2006, Gottfried performed with the [University of
Pennsylvania](/wiki/University_of_Pennsylvania "University of Pennsylvania")'s
[Mask and Wig](/wiki/Mask_and_Wig "Mask and Wig") Club in their annual
Intercollegiate Comedy Festival. Also in 2006, he made an appearance on the
_[Let's Make a Deal](/wiki/Let%27s_Make_a_Deal "Let's Make a Deal")_ portion
of _[Gameshow Marathon](/wiki/Gameshow_Marathon_\(US_TV_series\) "Gameshow
Marathon \(US TV series\)")_ (as a baby in a large [high
chair](/wiki/High_chair "High chair"), he says "Hey [Ricki](/wiki/Ricki_Lake
"Ricki Lake"), I think I need my diaper changed!"), and in the [Dodge
Viper](/wiki/Dodge_Viper "Dodge Viper") in the big deal (where he tells the
contestants "What were you thinking?!" because neither one picked it). He also
guest-starred in _[The Grim Adventures of Billy and
Mandy](/wiki/The_Grim_Adventures_of_Billy_and_Mandy "The Grim Adventures of
Billy and Mandy")_ as [Santa Claus](/wiki/Santa_Claus "Santa Claus") in the
one-hour Christmas Special. He voiced Rick Platypus in an episode of _[My Gym
Partner's a Monkey](/wiki/My_Gym_Partner%27s_a_Monkey "My Gym Partner's a
Monkey")_ entitled ["That Darn
Platypus"](/wiki/List_of_My_Gym_Partner%27s_a_Monkey_episodes "List of My Gym
Partner's a Monkey episodes").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Writer%27s_Guild_of_America_East_Soladarity_Rally_in_Washington_Square_cropped.jpg/220px-
Writer%27s_Guild_of_America_East_Soladarity_Rally_in_Washington_Square_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:Writer%27s_Guild_of_America_East_Soladarity_Rally_in_Washington_Square_cropped.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Writer%27s_Guild_of_America_East_Soladarity_Rally_in_Washington_Square_cropped.jpg
"Enlarge")

Gottfried at the Writers Guild of America East Solidarity Rally in [Washington
Square](/wiki/Washington_Square_Park "Washington Square Park") on November 27,
2007

He appeared as Peter's horse in an episode of _[Family Guy](/wiki/Family_Guy
"Family Guy")_ entitled "[Boys Do Cry](/wiki/Boys_Do_Cry "Boys Do Cry")" (in
which [Peter Griffin](/wiki/Peter_Griffin "Peter Griffin") is enthused to
learn that Gottfried is providing the horse's voice). He also guest-starred in
_[Hannah Montana](/wiki/Hannah_Montana "Hannah Montana")_ as Barny Bittmen. In
January 2009, Gottfried worked again with [David
Faustino](/wiki/David_Faustino "David Faustino") for an episode of Faustino's
show _[Star-ving](/wiki/Star-ving "Star-ving")_.[7] In 2011, Gottfried
appeared in the episode "Lost Traveler" on _[Law& Order: Special Victims
Unit](/wiki/Law_%26_Order:_Special_Victims_Unit "Law & Order: Special Victims
Unit")_ as Leo Gerber, a sarcastic computer professional working for the
[NYPD](/wiki/NYPD "NYPD")'s Technical Assistance Response Unit, which producer
[Warren Leight](/wiki/Warren_Leight "Warren Leight") said could become a
recurring character.[8] Gottfried read a section from the hit book _[Fifty
Shades of Grey](/wiki/Fifty_Shades_of_Grey "Fifty Shades of Grey")_ in a June
2012 YouTube video, which was created with the aim of using Gottfried's
trademark voice to make fun of the book's graphic sexual content.[9]

In 2013, Gottfried became a member of "Team [Rachael](/wiki/Rachael_Ray
"Rachael Ray")" on the second season of [Food Network](/wiki/Food_Network
"Food Network")'s _[Rachael vs. Guy: Celebrity Cook-
Off](/wiki/Rachael_vs._Guy:_Celebrity_Cook-Off "Rachael vs. Guy: Celebrity
Cook-Off")_. In March 2013 he appeared on
[ABC](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company")'s
_[Celebrity Wife Swap](/wiki/Wife_Swap_\(U.S._TV_series\)#Celebrity_Wife_Swap
"Wife Swap \(U.S. TV series\)")_. He swapped wives with [Alan
Thicke](/wiki/Alan_Thicke "Alan Thicke").[10] He is also a commentator on
_[truTV Presents: World's
Dumbest...](/wiki/TruTV_Presents:_World%27s_Dumbest... "TruTV Presents:
World's Dumbest...")_.

On May 28, 2014, Sideshow Network premiered _Gilbert Gottfried 's Amazing
Colossal Podcast_, an interview series where Gottfried and his co-host [Frank
Santopadre](/wiki/Frank_Santopadre "Frank Santopadre") discuss classic movies
and talk to "Hollywood legends and behind-the-scenes talents" who shaped
Gottfried's childhood and influenced his comedy.[11] His first guest was [Dick
Cavett](/wiki/Dick_Cavett "Dick Cavett").

Gottfried was the third contestant fired during [the seventh
season](/wiki/The_Apprentice_\(U.S._season_14\) "The Apprentice \(U.S. season
14\)") of the [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC") [reality show](/wiki/Reality_television
"Reality television") _[The Celebrity
Apprentice](/wiki/The_Celebrity_Apprentice "The Celebrity Apprentice")_.
Gottfried's most recent role came in 2016 when he played the 'Pig Man' in a
comedy/fantasy film _Abnormal Attraction_.[12]

## Personal
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gilbert_Gottfried&action=edit&section=4&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Personal life")]

In the late 1990s, Gottfried met Dara Kravitz at a [Grammy
Awards](/wiki/Grammy_Award "Grammy Award") party. They were married in 2007
and have two children together, daughter Lily and son Max.[13] They reside in
the [Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea,_Manhattan "Chelsea, Manhattan") neighborhood of
[Manhattan](/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan"). Gottfried was raised in a [Jewish
family](/wiki/American_Jews "American Jews"), but he has commented on his
podcast that he did not have a bar mitzvah.[14] One of his sisters was [Arlene
Gottfried](/wiki/Arlene_Gottfried "Arlene Gottfried"), a New York Street
photographer, who died in 2017.

## Comedic
style[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gilbert_Gottfried&action=edit&section=5&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Comedic style")]

Danny Gallagher of the _[Dallas Observer](/wiki/Dallas_Observer "Dallas
Observer")_ wrote that "Gottfried has one of the most original formulas in the
history of comedy", adding: "You don't just laugh at the punchline when
Gilbert Gottfried tells a joke. You laugh at the setup. You laugh at his
comments about the joke. You even laugh at the segues between his jokes."[15]
Gottfried is known for speaking in a loud and grating voice, which is not his
natural speaking voice.[16] Mark Binneli of _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ described Gottfried as a
"squinting, squawking mass of contradictions", noting his status as "one of
America's filthiest stand-ups and one of the most successful voice-over
artists in children's entertainment."[17] Gottfried is known for joking about
recent tragedies. In a July 2012 [op-ed](/wiki/Op-ed "Op-ed") for
[CNN](/wiki/CNN "CNN"), he wrote: "I have always felt comedy and tragedy are
roommates. If you look up comedy and tragedy, you will find a very old picture
of two masks. One mask is tragedy. It looks like it's crying. The other mask
is comedy. It looks like it's laughing. Nowadays, we would say, 'How tasteless
and insensitive. A comedy mask is laughing at a tragedy mask.'"[18]

## Controversial
jokes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gilbert_Gottfried&action=edit&section=6&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Controversial jokes")]

### 1991 Emmy
Awards[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gilbert_Gottfried&action=edit&section=7&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: 1991 Emmy Awards")]

At the [43rd Primetime Emmy Awards](/wiki/43rd_Primetime_Emmy_Awards "43rd
Primetime Emmy Awards"), Gottfried made "an endless series of masturbation
jokes" in reference to [Paul Reubens](/wiki/Paul_Reubens "Paul Reubens")'
arrest for masturbating in an adult movie theater.[19] Viewers on the east
coast saw the entire set live, but Fox censored the broadcast for the west
coast delay.[20] Fox issued an apology, stating that Gottfried's jokes were
"irresponsible and insulting".[19] Gottfried said that producers stated he
would not be invited back,[21] and _[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone
"Rolling Stone")_ wrote that the monologue resulted in him being
"blacklisted".[17]

### September 11
joke[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gilbert_Gottfried&action=edit&section=8&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: September 11 joke")]

During his monologue at a [Friars Club](/wiki/New_York_Friars%27_Club "New
York Friars' Club") [roast](/wiki/Roast_\(comedy\) "Roast \(comedy\)") of
[Hugh Hefner](/wiki/Hugh_Hefner "Hugh Hefner") three weeks after the
[September 11 attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks"),
Gottfried joked that he had intended to catch a plane, but could not get a
direct flight because "they said they have to stop at the [Empire State
Building](/wiki/Empire_State_Building "Empire State Building") first". This
was one of the first public examples of [9/11 humor](/wiki/9/11_humor "9/11
humor"). Audience members responded with hisses and a cry of "Too soon!"
Gottfried then abandoned his prepared remarks and launched into the venerable
[Aristocrats joke](/wiki/The_Aristocrats_\(joke\) "The Aristocrats \(joke\)"),
winning back the audience.[22] [Penn Jillette](/wiki/Penn_Jillette "Penn
Jillette") and [Paul Provenza](/wiki/Paul_Provenza "Paul Provenza") used
Gottfried's monologue as a segment in their 2005 film _[The
Aristocrats](/wiki/The_Aristocrats_\(film\) "The Aristocrats \(film\)")_.[23]

### Japanese tsunami
jokes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gilbert_Gottfried&action=edit&section=9&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Japanese tsunami jokes")]

In March 2011, Gottfried made a series of jokes on his [Twitter](/wiki/Twitter
"Twitter") account about the [earthquake disaster in
Japan](/wiki/2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami "2011 Tōhoku earthquake
and tsunami").[24] [Aflac](/wiki/Aflac "Aflac"), which does 75% of its
business in Japan, responded by dismissing Gottfried from voicing its [duck
mascot](/wiki/Aflac#The_Aflac_Duck "Aflac") on March 14, 2011, and announced a
casting call for his replacement as the voice of the duck.[25] He was replaced
by Daniel McKeague (who did an impression of Gottfried) on April 26, 2011.[26]
